Section 7, Page 24																										[24]  It will appear that these expenditures have been diffused over  nearly every state; not to the same amount in each, because, as  must be evident to every reflecting mind, it is not every state -whiA  has, within its limits, harbors or rivers which require improvement  or which admit of being improved. But every state must experienn  the benefit of improved harbors and rivers of an adjoining state,  Much misconception has arisen in reference to amounts which have  been appropriated for these harbors and rivers. Allow me to call  your attention to page 25 of the report, marked No. 2. It is there  stated, that the whole amounts appropriated (from 1806 to I845)  are,  For lake harbors $2,790,500  For the western rivers 2,758,800  By which it will be perceived, that the whole amount appropriated  and expended on these two interesting and important parts of the  system, does not exceed $5,549,300.  These facts are adapted to dissipate many erroneous impressions,  and to correct many errors.  Now, if it be desirable to know how the balance ofthe seventeen  millions over and above the amount for lake harbors and for western  rivers has been expended, the information will be found in the report  marked No. 1.  By referring to the facts of the report marked No. 3, it will be  perceived that  The nett commerce of the lakes was, for 1848     $93,242,633  And for the western rivers, for the year 1849     256,233,820  As the " exports" of one place are presumed to be the " imports  of another, the "nett commerce" is taken to be one half of "exports  and imports." These latter constituting what may be called the  " gross commerce," which last would be double the amounts stated.  This idea is not rigidly correct. "Without doubt, the " nett commerce" is more than half of the " gross commerce." But yet it was  considered the safe rule to adopt. Reasoning upon such a subject,  to obtain credit, should exhibit the desire of avoiding exaggeration,  or of assuming conjecture as a basis of the reasoning.  The passenger trade on the lakes, (see page 5 of the report  No. 3,) can be stated for the year 1849, at, passengers      356,000  And, supposing the passengers to have a direct relation to  tonnage and amount of trade, the passenger trade on the  western waters may be safely stated, for the same year, at.  passengers '   1,500,000  From these facts can be inferred sound reasons why so many ra";  roads are well supported, and why so many are required, as, withou  this immense internal trade,  and the consequent number of passe  gers, these rail-roads would be without support. 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2249	2249	2250.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2250.jp2
Section 7, Page 25																										[25]  It is considered that the lake trade alone has made necessary the  .. roa(j from Buffalo to Albany ; the rail-road from Dunkirk to  !? ff.York ; the rail-road from Albany to Boston, and the rail-road  fom Albany to New-York.    The various branches  to these great  ads derive their chief support from the same causes, the vast  'mount of internal trade and the passenger trade winch it generates.  The same reasoning and causes are applicable to the southern railroads. How few of these would exist, if local patronage were their  sole support.  We are indebted to Europe for many of the most useful mechanic  arts • but Europe is indebted to us for the great moral mechanics  which best develop the energies and resources of a people, and which  brin** into profitable activity the industry and capacity of every  member of the great body politic.  Referring effects to adequate and palpable causes, I believe it is to  be demonstrated, that this rapid and immense development of internal trade, this better than the mines of California, diffusing employment, wealth and happiness throughout our vastly extended  country, is owing chiefly to the very limited patronage which has, as  yet, been extended by the general government to our Lake Harbor  and Western River improvements. This patronage has populated  those regions, and has thrown a vast amount of wild land into useful  cultivation. Because it has furnished the means by which the products of the soil can find a market, exempt from consuming charges  of transportation, and in return by increasing the means, has increased  the wants of the cultivator and his ability to supply them.  The propriety of any particular rail-road project is to be decided  by reference to this great trade, in the benefits of which it will participate ; and there can hardly be a project of a road, which shall form  a link in the connection between the western rivers, or the lake harbors and the Atlantic, which will not partake of these as well as of  local benefits.  But it appears to me that this great chain will be incomplete, and  its benefits be but partially enjoyed, unless the connection be formed  between the Mississippi and the Pacific. Of the rail-road to insure  this connection, I have written several letters, but probably the last  ls p that you would desire to read.    I send a copy of this.  "appears to me that such a road, connecting with the Mississippi  some point so far south as to be exempt from interruption from  ■ce, would make New-Orleans the  great emporium for. the Pacific  |he connection between the Mississippi end of* the road and New-  neans, as well as with other points on that river, would probably  ano      accomplished by steamboat. Section 7, Page 26																										[26]  The various Isthmus routes with the Pacific have occupied m, l  attention. Allow me to send an interesting printed letter on th  subject, from Brevet Colonel Hughes, ofthe Corps.*  But these several routes have always appeared to me open to sen  ous objections.  1st. From the time they require.  2d. From interruptions in the continuity of the voyage, by fre_  quent changes from land to sea, and the consequent different modes  of transportation.  3d. They would of necessity become prolific sources of maritime  wars, and of consequent interruptions in the trade.  4th. They are out of our jurisdiction and control.  5th. The money required in the construction of parts would be for  the benefit of a foreign people and of foreign soil.  6lh. In all suspensions of the trade from war or other durable  cause, the inland parts would necessarily become dilapidated or destroyed ; and when these causes of interruption had subsided, there  is no telling how much time and how much money would be required  to restore the way to use, and to bring commerce back again to these  channels, wrhich the interruption had forced to be changed.  7th. Expenses on these routes must necessarily be great.  8th. The armed fleets which the protection of the commerce on  these routes would require, would involve most serious national ex-  penses. The nation could better afford to give half the cost of a continuous rail-road from the Mississippi.  A war of one year, with its cost, and consequent losses of all  kinds—a war resulting from circumstances necessarily attending any  one of these Isthmus routes, would probably amount to more than  the making of the entire road from the Mississippi.  These Isthmus routes are good temporary expedients; but the  durable and really valuable route is, in my opinion, to be found only  in a continuous rail-road route from the Mississippi to the Pacific  within our own jurisdiction.  Respectfully, sir, your obedient servant,  J. J. Abert,  Col. Corps Top. Engineers.  Glenoy Burke, Esq.,  Chairman, &c, dec, New-Orleans. 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2251	2251	2252.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2252.jp2

Dear Sir: I have at last been able to have those letters copied, about  ,    oa(j and now send them to you.   In reference to probable cost, recent  formation induces me to believe, that a road from the Mississippi to the  Rio Grande, passing at the head of sea-navigation of all the principal rivers  rtf Texas which communicate with the gulf, could be made for less than I  formerly supposed.  If we take this distance at 850 miles, and the average cost of each mile.  to make the rail-road complete, and bring it into use, at $40,000 the mile,  it will make the cost of that part of the road $34,000,000.  If this part alone of the road was made, it would command all the travel.  For from the Rio Grande to San Diego, is a frontier Une of the United  State**, on which military posts will have to be established, and roads connecting with these posts will have to be made, which will make that route  passable and safe, and wall occasion it gradually to become settled, and sooner  or later to be turned into a rail-road. Eut we will suppose the whole to be  a rail-road, and endeavor to estimate its probable cost and probable profits.  From the Paso to San Diego on the Pacific, is about 850 miles. If it be  supposed that this part of the route will cost 50 per cent, more than the  average cost per mile from the Mississippi to Paso, it will make the average  of this part of the road $00,000 the mile, and bring the total cost of these  850 miles to $51,000,000.    Then the whole road will cost as follows :  850 miles from the Mississippi to Paso, $34,000,000  850 miles from Paso to San Diego  51.000,000  Total, $85,000,000  Twelve per cent, upon such an outlay would require an income of  $10,200,000. This would be a gross income, out of which all expenses for  repairs, attendance, &c, -fee, &c. would have to be taken. Taking these at  half the gross income, it would leave $5,100,000 to be divided, in order to  yield an income upon the stock of G per cent, per annum.  The question now occurs, from what sources will this road derive such  au income ?   We will consider two sources only—travelers and freight.  lrf. Travelers.—In my letter of the 24th September, 1849, I take these  at 50 each way per day, for 350 days, and at a charge of $68 for a through  passage.  An extremely judicious friend, who has given much attention to these  matters, says, that I am seriously wrong in both these items—seriously be-  °w the reality in reference to the number of travelers, and equally below  What would be considered a cheap charge for the distance.  In his opinion 100 passengers, each way, would yet be much below the re-  ny, and $150 for each passenger vastly below what each has now to pay.  "M at these rates, and with the time saved, the road would, without doubt,  command the travel of the world from the Atlantic to the Pacific.    Taking  2rf rpG3' tlie income from passengers would be $10,500,000.  a- flight—The same friend has remarked, that the road should be  i ui reference to the commerce it would generate and command, and  ■hoi's ?efcrence to anJ" Proflt from freight.    That, except for passengers, it  u'a be a free road, making no charge for freight, thereby enabling it to  I "umaad the commerce of the world with the Pacific; and from this mo- 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2252	2252	2253.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2253.jp2
Section 7, Page 28																										L28]  nopoly of commerce, vastly more wealth would be secured to the countr»  than could possibly be from any profit by a charge of freight and a con'  sequently restricted commerce.  Freight is unquestionably a serious tax upon commerce ; and the m0r  freights are reduced, the more profitable commerce must be, and the mot-!  extensive its range. But the argument of my friend is, I think, in a cagp  like this pushed to an extreme; and, in my opinion, the whole commerce  between the Atlantic and Pacific may bo monopolized and commanded by  a moderate freight charge, making it vastly the cheaper o^ any route.  It is considered a good passage from New-York to San Francisco, by  Cape Horn, if it occupy no more than 5 months, or 150 days. Now, by'thg  rail-road route, as exhibited in my letter of the 24th September, 1849 a  passenger train would move over this distance, at a rate of 20 miles the  hour, in 11 days; and to San Diego in 8 days. At 15 miles the hour it  would require to San Francisco, 13 days; to San Diego, 10 days. And at  the slow rate of 10 miles the hour, the time to reach San Francisco would  be 17 days; to San Diego, 14 days.  Take any of these rates, and compare them with the 150 clays ofthe  usual sea voyage, and the difference is so vastly in favor of the road,'as to  ensure to it the monopoly of the whole trade. The point then to be guarded against is, not to destroy this decided and important advantage in time  by an exorbitant freight charge.  Suppose, then, that no higher freight were charged on the road, than is  charged on the sea-voyage ; then, the moneyed charge would be the same on  the road as on the sea-voyage, and all the diftbrcwe of time would be  gained by the shipper, a difference so vastly in his favor, that it must prevent all shipments by sea, and insure the whole trade to the road; and  not only is there this difference in time in favor of the road, but the difference of interest upon the freight saved by time to the shipper, which would  frequently be more than equivalent to the road-freight charge, and make  the rail-road tantamount to a free road.  These considerations fulfil all the conditions of my friend's reasoning, in  reference to the advantages of a free road, and yet justify a charge for  wear, tear, and repairs, and for freight trains.  The average shipping freight charge is $25* the tun. which, on 150,000  tuns, would yield $3,750,000.  By the passenger trade we have $10,500,000  And by the freight, as above,     3,750,000  Making a total of $14,250,000  But the income required to insure 6 per cent- upon the stock (after paying all annual expenses) is $10,200,000: we have therefore from these two  considerations (passengers and freight) an excess ol' four millions, winch  would justify a reduction of the charge per passenger to $100 each; ot»  will justify a serious reduction of our supposition in reference to amount «  freight trade. Wooldridge, Esq., en^W  of the state, who had previously carried a survey over the same region, \^  matter of constructing a road over this country—the dreaded Mississippi Swain  —is the only real or unusual difficulty which was anticipated on the route, I hi  to state that I consider these difficulties to have been much exaggerated, a'ndtW  the swamp is not impracticable for the construction of a permanent work/a  reasonable cost. The material is not properly that of a swamp or morass, bn!  merely the deposit from the waters not yet high enough to escape the annual  overflows. When dry, it is tenacious and firm, which character it maintains to  indefinite depths.  Mr. Murrell's well, on the banks of the Bonne Idee, 27 feet deep, and lower  than the bottom of the bayou, showed at the bottom gravel as large as a hickory  nut, mixed with a chocolate-colored clay. In certain places in the swamp, stand.  ing water does not penetrate below a few inches. Hence an embankment of any  weight may be sustained, and constructions of masonry be made permanent by a  good platform foundation below. Neither is the soil of a quality to " run" insiiil  water, though in certain cases it might be advisable to give the sides of the em.  bankments a flatter slope than is usual.  Timber of excellent quality abounds; the "over-cup oak" is the prevailing  growth ofthe swamp, and no timber is better for constructions of the character  we are discussing.  I saw the string-pieces of abridge over the Bonne Idee which were built of this  timber. It was partly submerged in ordinary seasons, and entirely so at timesof  flood, the weight being sufficient to keep it from floating.  This timber was perfectly sound, although it had been lying ten years in that  very trying position. The soil of much of the country is proper for bricks;  hence, wilh durable timber, good earth for embankment, and materials for brick,  we have at hand all the requisites for the road.  I conclude, therefore, that there is no objection on account of unusual difficulties of construction, excepting the interruption and injury to incomplete works  from high water, which latter may be guarded against by bringing the embankments, as far as constructed, to their full heights, and when the water is about to  rise, protecting the extremities by revetments of timber and plank. The embankment of a road always above water would be, for the greater part of the distance,  less than ten feet in height, and never twenty feet, excepting for a few hundred  feet in length at the approaches of the streams. Hence tbe cost will not be so  formidable as has been imagined. But the great question is, if the construction  of such a bank across the whole swamp will not be making a dam to hold bw  the freshet water, and thus bring it to a higher level, doing injury to_the country  above and to the work itself. It would seem that, if there were any impediment  to the movement of the immense mass of water which, in seasons of flood, cove*  -the country for many miles inland, it would cause the water to rise agaiusta  over the bank, and finally sweep it away, after having doue great "'J"^,10^  upper country. Of course, if openings of sufficient magnitude be not left t^vC  the embankment, such will be the effect, though less in degree than would^  produced by corresponding circumstances in a mountainous region, w"e.,  floods rush in from their sources, or where the face of the country lias a coiisi ^^  ble slope. But there is no reason why openings of sufficient magnitude s .  not be made, for these, as will presently appear, need not be so considera f  would be judged without observation. The  difference of a foot in the level of the surface of the water above and below the  bank would cause the passage of a body of water under such bridges as we propose to construct, many times greater than would be passed with the ordinary  sluggish movement of the waters.  This holding back of the water would continue but for a few days before it  would be brought to equilibrium, or retire to its proper channels, and leave the  cultivated country above ready for the labors of the planters. It is, moreover,  not necessary to proceed rashly in the construction, as it is possible to prepare  ihe work for travel before contracting the openings to their permanent minimum.  For this I would, in the beginning, construct none but the lighter embankments of  earth; and as all the places of the heavier embankments are in the approaches to  Ujb openings, I would make a temporary substitute of trestles at those places,  until by minute observation, precise knowledge on the proper permanent contraction could be obtained. By this means another object would be subserved,  by providing a way for the transportation of the materiel for the permanent  work. More space has been given to the discussion of this „  ofthe route than will be to any equal extent of the remainder, for the reason ft  little knowledge and much misapprehension exists on the subject of the prac.:at  bility of ways through the " Mississippi swamp," and because the observatin*  made have general application to other parts of the swamp than that over which  the  line was carried, and probably to the whole region subject to overflow  formed by deposit from the Mississippi River.  On leaving the swamp, our line passed near the residence of Captain Knox  over Prairie Mer Rouge, and in a distance of four miles came to an abrupt rise  from the plane called the Red Hill, which is the border of a range of hills slated  to begin at Pine Bluff, on the Arkansas River, and, running southerly, to cross the  Bayou Bartholomew about 12 miles above Prairie Mer Rouge; whence, con.  turning to the south, they cross our line and diminish in height, until they are km  in a table which reaches the Washita, near the plantation of Senator DownB. We  passed through the town of Bastrop, which is built on these hills, and found its  elevation to be sixty feet above the prairie, and about one hundred feet above  the water of the Bartholomew.  Two miles beyond Bastrop we strike that bayou at Point Pleasant, sixty feel  lower than Bastrop, but still above high water ; we then followed the general  course of the bayou on good ground all the way to the Washita, crossing Bayon  Saira and Bayou Bosuf, which now discharge their waters into the Washita, but  which, in high stages, reverse the direction of their flow and assist in carrying it  off. These will require bridges. By following the bayou, we are carried three  miles to the south, out of our way, to Collier's Point, the place selected lor  crossing the Washita ; but we avoid by this two crossings, with draw bridges, of  the Bartholomew, in case we continue to Collier's; or one if we consent to cross  the Washita at the village above Collier's, which is an inferior place, and involving heavier expenditure. The line from Knox's just described, and which waa  traced on the|ground, is not the one proposed for construction. The bends of  the Bartholomew are too abrupt, and the Bastrop hills would require deep excavation. I would, therefore, starting from Knox's, leave Bastrop about two milei  on the right, or north, and run through the foot of the hills, where they have  inferior elevation; thence to the southernmost point of the bend of the Bartholomew, on the plantation of Senator Downs, when we fall into the line as traced on  the ground. From this southern point we turn northerly three miles, until we  arrive on the bank of the Washita, opposite to Collier's Point, which, as befort  Btated, is the place selected for crossing. This projected line is on lower ground  than that actually traced, being sixty feet lower opposite Bastrop than the ground  occupied by that village : this is judged of by the depth of Beauchamp's well,**'  his brick.yard ; but the greater directness, easier grades, and lighter excavation  through the hills, serve to sanction the selection of the route.  The material composing the Bastrop Hills is sand and clay ; the water stratum,  80 feet in depth, is a fine white sand.   The clay is good for brick-making,aD  many are made in the vicinity. This is a period in the history of the world in which advancement is emphatically the order ot" the day ; kingdoms and empires that have been slumberiug lor  ages are now awaking to tbe importance of intercommunication upon the we!|.  being of man, and are exerting their gigantic energies to open great highways of  commerce throughout the world.  The arts and sciences are advancing with a rapidity never before known ; while  new discoveries and inventions give facility and impetus to the onward march of  our race to the ultimatum of human destiny.  The spirit of improvement has seized upon the masses of the people; and in  wide-spread influence is seen aud felt in its meliorating effects upon their physical,  intellectual, and moral condition.  Where this spirit has prevailed, it has overcome prejudice; aroused indolence lo  energy; supineness to effort; given new impulses to trade, and multiplied the  sources of wealth and happiness to the laboriug classes.  Cheap and rapid communication between the interior and our seaboard towni  is a subject ofthe most vita! importance to our prosperity and well-being.  Men of eminent ability, whose genius is guided in its researches by the light of  revelation, as well as of reason, have taken up this subject with an earnestness  which its importance invites, aud presented the result of their observations to the  public, which has been reflected upon the dark portions of the world, until its  reciprocal blessings are felt by all.  Of all tbe means of artificial inland intercommunication, rail-roads afford tiie  most desirable facilities, which modern developments, in their adaptation for transportation and travel, have so far engrafted upon tbe business of the country, as'°  render them absolutely necessary to our prosperity.  The assembling  of this Convention   may   well   be  considered as the m«t  irnportantepochiu the history of Louisiana, and the South-western states genertU/i  and it is proper that we avail ourselves of the present aroused sentiment ot  people, to establish and permanently engraft upon this portion ofthe coU|ltr7?  its administration, such a system of infernal improvement aw shall be best calcii  in its progress and final completion, to connect and bring to one common con  ing point, the products of this portion of our country. .       f ^e  The city of New-Orleans may justly be considered the great emporiiani °- ^  South; the commercial centre and heart of this portion of our confederacy; ^  whence, if she is true to herself, must radiate an influence that, wh»at ' .^  bring to her increased wealth, cannot fail to send abroad, even to the shores o^  Pacific, an influence which will cross that ocean, and bring back rich return^^  the eastern dominions of Asia. The  time has come when timid, or doubtful half-way facilities for trade and travel, will  wither promote nor satisfy the enterprising march of all the commercial and  industrial pursuits of this advancing age. Again: of the progress and position of the Pacific States, the world, and it*  history, does not afford a parallel. The discovery of the rich mines has enticed  aud congregated there thousands of people, of all nations, kindred and tonsuM  reared and educated under various forms of government, many with unbr«]|J  passions, unaccustomed to our institutions and laws, hard to govern in their n™.  sent position, which gives them the command of the commerce of the Pacific  with China, and with all Asia. Hence tbe more immediate the necessity of  opening a great highway, facilitating trade, the interchange of commodities between tbe two oceans, and an immense population of consumers in the intermediate valley. This is not a new subject; it has been for a long time before the  public, discussed and commented upon in every quarter; but the positional  present assumed is different. We ask for these grunts to be made directly to  corporations, created and controlled within their proper sphere by state authority, involving no constitutional difficulties.  To illustrate : an eminent writer upon the subject of private corporations, remarks,—only a few years since " Professor Morse deemed the construction of  an extensive electric telegraph impracticable, except by the general government,  who repelled him, as it had repelled De Witt Clinton, when he supposed the  Erie Canal could not be built without aid from the national treasury; hiid to  these refusals we owe the numerous telegraphs which are pervading our country,  aud the numerous canals and rail-roads with which the states have enriched their  respective sovereignties; improvements greatly mure extensive than the general  government could have accomplished, had it been ever mo willing. The United  States in their agencies seem naturally obdurate. In a degree proportioned to  their unfitness, men in their aspirations naturally call upon some Hercules, instead of eliciting an energetic exercise of their own powers. But weevobe  principles practically, long before we see them speculatively, or we should not  persevere, as we do, in a reliance on the general government for what we term  internal improvements; and which, except for such reliance, would readily be  accomplished to every profitable extent, by our states individually, or their people : a sufficient reason why our states increased so rapidly in power, after their  separation from Great Britain.  Pennsylvania and Michigan, which relied on state agency for the construction of  rail-roads, became insolvent and unable to complete their undertakings; wMl"  the states of New-York and Massachusetts, who constructed theirs by private  corporations, completed more rail-roads than the former states ever contemplated. Wise, therefore, is the policy which, by means of private incorporations,  enables individuals to combine their resources, and thus to extend the sphere ol  personal efficiency, the great reservoir of all efliciency. .   ,  Il is neither my province nor my pleasure to depreciate the claims ol r^a  routes, for a road through Arkansas, that may be, in the estimation of others*e*"  titled to a priority of consideration by this Convention. A diversion  from this recommendation might greatly retard, if not blight, for years, our pros-  nuriiv; and I crave indulgence to press these humble sentiments upon your attention, and bespeak for tbem an attentive consideration, such as shall be commensurate witli its importance.  It is, perhaps, known to most of you, that tbe name of Arkansas has become  a by-word and reproach, upon which to heap every vile epithet that is degrading  to a free and enlightened people. Why it is so, except from habit, I cannot say.  Arkansas, not unlike most of the Western States of her age, has, perhaps by unwise legislation, placed herself and her people in tbe back-ground for awhile,  and to some extent, and by that means, oppressed the energies of many of her  best citizens; but the day is beginning to dawn, and a bright future is close at  hand, when, by a change in our constitution and laws, we shall be relieved from  onr long-existing financial embarrassments, which have borne us down to such a  degree, that our natural energies and immense resources cannot be made available for advancing either our manufacturing or internal improvement interests.  Still, I am authorized to say, that we shall be able to survey, locate, and commence the work upon our portion of these proposed roads, as soon as the public  policy of the country will authorize it. and the South-western States shall have  decided upon and established a system, as a guide, if such should be their pleasure. It is with great reluctance that I state these things, or thus attempt to  speak for the state in which I live, lest from incompetency, or a misapprehension  of her real interests or policy, I might unconsciously err in my efforts to place  her ia the right position. Nor would I attempt to speak under any circumstances, except as at present advised there is no certainty that any of our distinguished citizens will be present from this portion of the state, to represent her in  the Convention. No man, however intelligent he may be, can be fully aware of  the facts that really exist in relation to the practical effects of internal improvements in a new country, unless he makes it a study; nor their means and  their availability to build these roads, consisting, as they do, in a counny like  onrs, of labor, teams, materials, provisions and money. nor is it easy, in reference to a "main trunk  tne&gt; of the extent and dimensions of tbe one under consideration, to form any  correct estimate of the local traffic and travel that will concentrate upon it; Section 8, Page 3																										ADDRESS  Fellow Citizens:  In appealing to yon for aid and a  struction of the New Orleans, Opelousas and Great Western Railroad, the Board of Directors have thought it  incumhent on them to present you some facts in relation  to this grand enterprise, to which they most respectfully  call your attention.  This Company is permanently organized under a charter to construct a railroad from Algiers to Washington,  in the Parish of St. Landry, via. Thibodaux, Berwick's  Bay, New Iberia, &c, a distance of about one hundred  and sixty miles, by which all the rich section of our  State, which is almost entirely ciit off from access to  this City during several months in the year, will be  placed within a few hours proximity, at all times and at  &gt;U seasons.  There is no- portion of Louisiana which affords the  s*me advantages for the developement of those resources  °n which the inhabitants of this City depend for the necessary articles of food.    By  the construction  of  this 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2322	2322	2323.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2323.jp2
Section 8, Page 4																										work, our supplies of beef, mutton, poultrv n  1 uuiuy. the produce  of the dairy, fruits, vegetables, &c, &c., would be  siderably increased, and be sold at greatly reduced  the  mechanic, the   laboring  man, in fact every h  keeper in the city would derive an immediate and certain  benefit from the opening of this road.  In connection with this, it cannot be denied thai 0Be  of the prominent causes which have retarded our gtowth  as a city, is the high price or cost of living, and any.  thing done towards ameliorating this heavy burden, nti.i  great drawback on our prosperity, will tend to augmcm  our population and add to our resources. What we  most want is a permanent population, actively and prof.  itably employed. Situated as we are at present, we  have to depend entirely on the precarious navigation ol  the rivers and bayous; all our energies are called into  requisition during a few months in the year to meet its  exigencies, after which we remain comparatively idle  till the rivers rise the next season, and so on in succes  sion; trade in ail its branches, is thereby rendered precarious, and the enterprise of our merchants completely  The last two seasons navigation opened unusually  late, and hundreds of thousands of dollars have been  sunk by the loss of two months, when nearly all mt"'  course with the interior was suspended. The Board of Directors of the New Orleans, Opelousas  and Great Western Pvailroad Company, in recapitulating  some few ofthe great advantages which the property holders of this city may derive from this undertaking, conn,  dently rely on th-eir good judgment in sustaining this truly  Louisiana Road, the remote results of which are almost  incalculable to all classes of our population. New Orleans is pre-eminently a commercial city, and so long as  our commerce thrives, so long will the owners of real  estate derive an income from the capital invested in this  species of property, which must increase or decrease with  the growth or decline of the city. Population will always follow the laws of trade, and go where it derives  the most profit from its labor; not so with your houses  and lots; their fate is fixed, and here they must remain,  be our prospects good or bad. Section 9, Page 3																										BY-LAWS.  ARTICLE    I.  The tenure of all offices created and enumerated in the Charter  of the Company, or other employees in the service of the same, shall  be during the will of the Board of Direction. They shall be elective  at the 6rst meeting of the next Board, and annually thereafter; and  in case any officer is removed by the Board before the expir.-itinn of  the time for which lie was elected, he shall be entitled to pay only  for the term he may have been in the actual service of the Company,  and not for the whole period for which he was chosen.  ARTICLE    II.  It shall be the duty of the President to preside at all meetings of  the Board; to convoke it specially when he thinks proper, or upon  the written requisition of any five Directors ; to perform the office of  elect one; to exercise a general supervision and control over the  affairs and agents of the Company ; and to do and perform all other  duties not otherwise assigned or provided for. His salary shall he  81500 per annum, payable monthly on his own warrant.  ARTICLE    III.  14 shall be the duty of the Secretary to attend each meeting of  *&lt;&gt; Board; to keep an accurate and fair record of all its proceedings ;  to netify in writ;ng eacll ancj every meeting ; and to do and perform  « other duties that may he devolved upon him by either the Presi-  n or the Board.    He shall have charge and custody of all Records,  0 % Reports, Minutes, and other papers belonging to the Company.  6 shall keep the office of the Company, and be personally present 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2333	2333	2334.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2334.jp2
Section 9, Page 4																										ARTICLE    IV.  The duty of the Solicitor shall be to give his legal advice and  counsel when consulted ; to represent the Company in all the Court,  of Law or Equity, in suits to which they may be a party ; t0 giTe  his professional services and attention in the preparation of all acts  or other writings in which they may be interested ; and to afford any  other professional aid that may he required of him by the President  or the Board.    His salary shall be $500 per annum, payable monthly  ARTICLE V.  It shall be the duty of the Engineer to perform all duties which  appertain to his department of the service; to exercise a general  and personal supervision and control over his corps in the suhordinate  duties which may be assigned them ; to make weekly reports to the  Board, detailing the progress of his operations, and all other material  information connected with his work, or otherwise of interest to the  Company, and to strictly conform to the orders of the President and  the Board.   His salary shall he $ per annum, payable monthly  upon the warrant of the President.  ARTICLE VI.  The duty of the Superintendent shall consist in obedience to and  performance of all orders and instructions given him by the Direction,  in whatever branch or department of service that may be assigned  to him. His salary shall be $2000 per annum, payable monthly upon  the warrant of the President. Section 11, Page A2																										PROCEEDINGS  FIRST ANNUAL MEETING OF THE STOCKHOLDERS  NEW-ORLEANS, OPELOUSAS, AND GREAT WESTERN  RAIL ROAD COMPANY.  Pursuant to the provisions of the 10th section of the  Charter of the New Orleans, Opelousas, and Great Western Rail Road Company, and agreeably to public notice,  the Stockholders of said Company convened at their office  in New Orleans, on Monday, January 17th, 1853, at 12  o'clock, M.  On motion, S. W. Oakey, Esq., was called to the chair,  and Benj. F. Flanders appointed Secretary.  It appearing that a majority of the Stock was not represented, as required by the 10th section ofthe Charter, the  meeting was adjourned, in accordance with the provisions  aid section, for one week, viz : till January 24th, 1853. 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2375	2375	2376.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2376.jp2
Section 11, Page 4																										"Adjourned Meeting."  Monday, January 24(/i, I853.  The meeting was called to order at half past 6 o'clock  p. m., S. W. Oakey, in the chair.   Stockholders representing eight thousand seven hundred and fifty-five shares  were present.    The Chairman briefly stated the object of  The President of the Company submitted, on the part of  the Board of Directors, their first Annual Report, accompanied by the Report of the Chief Engineer. Both documents having been read, Mr. Wm. M. Goodrich offered the  following resolution, which was unanimously adopted:  Resolved, That this, the first Annual Report of the President and Directors to the Stockholders, with the accompanying documents, and a map of the proposed route of  this Road to the Sabine, and its extension through Texas,  Arkansas and Missouri, be published with the proceedings  of the Meeting, in pamphlet form, for general distribution  among the Stockholders; and that a copy of the same be  addressed by the Secretary to each Stockholder.  Resolved, That the Board of Directors be requested to  cause the said rcpuris to bo published in any newspapers in  this State or elsewhere, to enlighten the public mind as to  the importance of this great work, not only to the State of  Louisiana, but to the entire territory west of the Mississippi.  Mr. Denegre offered a resolution, fixing calls for further  installments, as required by the 3d section, of the Charter,  which, after being amended by G. B. Duncan, Esq... was  adopted as follows:  Resolved, That the President and Directors of this Com- 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2376	2376	2377.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2377.jp2

Thiswt 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2398	2398	2399.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2399.jp2
Section 11, Page 27																										27  A guage of 5 feet 6 inches has been adopted by the Company ;  this has been done with reference to connection with other Western  roads. The adoption of this guage by the Pacific or St. Louis Road,  and now by ours, will establish this as the uniform guage West of  the Mississippi River.  The grading of the whole road is very light. Over a large portion, the embankments are only rail igh to ensure  perfect drainage. From Berwick's Bay to Washington, with the  exception of about four miles, the whole line is high and dry above  any danger of overflow. A portion of the lower division is subject  to the overflow of crevasses. It has never been calculated to build  the road above high water mark—there would be many objections  to it. By it the cost of the road would be vastly increased, whilst  it would operate greatly to the injury of all the lands between the  road and the river. In the time of a crevasse instead of the water  being allowed to run back and spread over the swamps and low  ground, in the rear of the river, it would be dammed up by the embankments of the road, thereby causing the whole of the land next  the river to be overflowed. This plan would meet wilh violent opposition from all the planters on -the river. Instead of this, it is proposed to place as little obstruction as possible in the way of crevasse  water, by building our embankments sufficiently far from the river,  as to allow the force of the current to be spent before reaching  them, and building only so high as to ensure drainage, we sustain  no injury, except from a temporary delay in the  operation of the  Efficient means should also be taken to guard against crevasses,  by having all exposed points properly secured.  It is to be considered too, that the construction itself of the road,  will make the danger of crevasses less than they are now, as it will  be the means of speedy transportation of workmen and materials to  any point that may be threatened. Immediately where a crevasse  occurs, the water runs through it with great velocity, but it soon  spreads over a large extent of ground, losing its velocity as it recedes from the river, until at a distance of a half mile it is not sufficient to injure our embankments, protected as they will be by a  thick matting of grass and weeds.  d2 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2399	2399	2400.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2400.jp2

page 71																										Wells, the proprietor of the hotel went to the above-mentioned  place, and purchased twenty mattresses, which were shipped immediately to this place. I mention this fact, because it has been frequently remarked and reported through the country that the mattresses were ordered from New Orleans. About the middle of  August, two suspicious cases occurred, winch created considerable  alarm among the visitors, but not regarded as yellow fever by the  -ban. both of which died on the fourth or fifth day,  with symptoms of fever, but no black Vomit. Each of these cases  came from a fever district a few days before they were taken sick.  For a week or ten days there was no sickness of any description.  On the 23d of August, a lady from Louisiana was attacked with  fever; came through Vicksburg a short time before. On the 26th  of August Dr. Pugh was attacked (the Doctor attended the eases  above spoken of). Both of these oases died with black vomit on  the fifth day. The prominent symptoms in these, as well as many  other eases, were severe pain in the head, back, and calves of the  inicohni. skin yellow, often hot and dry, and frequently a profuse  stances, be kept up; tympanites and suppression of urine, coma and  black vomit, would generally end the same on the fourth or fifth,  and sometimes on the third day.   During the week that the two  of well-marked intermittent and remittent forms of fever, all of  whom got well, under a mild course of medication for those diseases. The fever then assumed a different type; the change was  gradual, a running into yellow fever as it were, and spread ra] .idly,  principally among the blacks.  At the commencement of the epidemic, dating from the 23d of  August, there were about four hundred persons a: .be Wells, white  and black, exposed up to the 31st of August, when the first death  took place. Yet, I only heard of two cases of fever occurring out  of this large number after they left Cooper's Wells. All who  remained were connected with the establishment, numbering fifty,  white and black. Of these, four had had the fever previously, and  one escaped an attack. There were forty-five attacks and nine  deaths—six whites and three blacks.  of Drs. Hubbard, Buckner, and Bricked, of Vicksburg, and Dr.  Cabaniss, of Jackson. A complete census of the 3d ward was taken by the Belief Com  mittee, which furnished the following statistics:—  Population—whites, 638; colored, 558; total, 1,196.  Fever cases—whites, 579; colored, 213; total, 792, or two-thirds  of the inhabitants.  Deaths—whites, 159; colored, 13; total, 172, or 21.70 per cent, of  the attacked. page 6																										GENERAL REMARKS.  MAYORALTY OF NEW ORLEANS. &gt;  City Hall, October 15th, 1856.     /  To the Officers-and Men of the Police  of the City of Neiv Orleans :  The object of placing a copy of this small volume in  the hands of every Policeman, is, that he shall have in  his possession, the means whereby he can become acquainted with the duties lie is required to perform.  The instructions as to the legal powers and duties of  Policemen should be carefully studied by every member  of the Department, for without a thorough and intimate knowledge of these Rules, Policemen will be fre-  qucntlj^d into error, and be the means, perhaps, of  ', ingi      el si .■■,1,1 upon the Department.  In preparing a work of this kind, it is impossible to  provide for every emergency that may arise, therefore  it will be required of every Policeman, not only to adhere strictly to the Rules laid down here, but also to  conform to such other orders, as may be issued from  time to time by the Mayor or Chief of Police.  It is expected that every member of the Department 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2644	2644	2645.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2645.jp2
page 7																										will observe a strict compliance "with the Rules and  Regulations, for it is only by such a compliance, and  by the energetic performance of duty, that the usefulness, harmony and character of the Police can be preserved.  Every member of the Department is expected to do  his duty, and one of the surest evidences of the faithful fulfilment of the responsible obligations imposed  upon the Police, will be found in the absence of crime,  and the prompt detection of criminals and offenders.  CHAS. M. WATERMAN, Mayor. 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2645	2645	2646.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2646.jp2
page 8																										RULES AND REGULATIONS  fltaal (Sabmamt of t\t 'Balm §tpxtmut  CITY OF NEW ORLEANS.  ARTICLE I.  Section 1. Every member connected with the  department shall devote his whole time and attention to the business of the department, and shall  not follow any other calling unless by special permission of the Mayor.  Sec. 2. Although certain hours are allotted to  each man's duty, yet all the members must be prepared to act at a moment's notice whenever their  services may be required.  Sec. 3. Punctual attendance shall be required,  on all occasions, of every officer and policeman  attached to the department. Three successive  days absence from duty, without leave, will be  considered good cause for dismissal. 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2646	2646	2647.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2647.jp2
page 9																										Sec. 4. They shall yield implicit obedience to  all lawful orders which they may receive from the  persons in authority over them.  Sec. 5. No person shall be permitted to remain  in the several Police Station Houses without express permission from the officer in charge, except  members of the department and  persons on busi-  Sec. 6. The use of Spiritous Liquors in the  Police Station Houses is expressly forbidden, nor  is it permitted to any policeman on Duty to enter  a Coffee House or Cabaret, unless in the immediate discharge of his duties. Policemen are required to be quiet and orderly, and are expressly  forbidden to use any obscene or improper language  while in or about the Station Houses.  Sec. 7. Members of the department shall not  accept from any person while in custody, or after  he shall have been discharged, nor from any of his  friends, any gratuity, reward or present, nor shall  they receive from any person (without the written  permission of the Mayor) compensation for damages sustained in the discharge of their duty.  Sec. 8. A perfect command of temper is a  qualification essentially necessary to a policeman, 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2647	2647	2648.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2648.jp2
page 10																										10  and will secure to him the support of every good  citizen in the discharge of his duty. It is, therefore, expected that members of the department  shall be civil and respectful to the public, and shall  on all occasions perform their duty with good  temper and discretion ; and must not, at any time,  make use of violent, intemperate or abusive language.  Sec. 9. No member will be permitted to apply  for a warrant, for an assault upon himself without  first reporting the case to the Chief of Police, and  obtaining from him or from the Mayor, permision  in writing to make such application. The object  -of this Section is to guard against unnecessary  and vexatious prosecutions, whilst, at the same  time, members will be efficiently protected by  every legal means in all cases that require protec-  Sec. 10. No member shall communicate to any  persons any information which may lead to the  escape from arrest or punishment of persons accused of crimes or misdemeanors; or which may  enable them to dispose of or secrete any goods  stolen or embezzled. Nor shall any member communicate,  except to such persons   as directed by 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2648	2648	2649.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2649.jp2
page 11																										his superior in of/ice, any information respecting  orders which he may have received, or any regulation that may he made for the government of  the department.  Sec. 11. Each member shall always have with  him a memorandum book, in which he shall enter  the names of such persons whom he may have  taken in custody ; and also such matters in each  case as will be important on the trial of the cause.  Sec. 12. Each member of the department shall  wear the emblem of office on his left breast, on  the outside of his outer garment.  Sec. 13. Lieutenants, Sergeants, and Policemen shall at all times and on all occasions, when  on duty, conspicuously display their crescent or  emblem of office.  Sec. 14. No member of the Police Department  shall leave the City without permission from the  Mayor.  Sec. 15. All persons who may be arrested during the time the Recorder's Courts may be open  in accordance with existing laws, shall be conveyed immediately to the Recorder's Court in the  District to which the policeman who made the  arrest shall be attached, unless otherwise directed 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2649	2649	2650.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2650.jp2
page 12																										by the Mayor or Chief of Police ; and all persons  who may be arrested after the hours in which the  Recorders' Courts are in session, shall be taken to  the Police Station House of the Policeman who  may make the arrest.  Sec. 16. Any property stolen or embezzled  which shall be found in the possession of any  person who may be arrested, shall be taken to the  Recorder's Court or Police Station House, as the  case may be, with the person arrested, unless  otherwise ordered by the Mayor or Chief of  Police.  Sec. 17. All property which shall come into  the possession of Policemen, whether stolen or lost,  shall be taken to the Police Station House and delivered to the officer there in charge; all articles  delivered to the officer in charge, as stated above,  shall,previous to their del very, be marked by the  Policeman, so that he may be able to identify them  afterwards; nor shall he deliver them until the  officer shall have made an entry in the proper  book of said articles, the Policeman having previously called out the description of the articles  for that purpose.  Sec.  18. Any member who shall charge or re- 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2650	2650	2651.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2651.jp2
page 13																										13  eeive any fee or compensation, other than his  legal salary, or shall receive any present or reward for services rendered or to be rendered, unless with the knowledge and approbation of the  Mayor or Chief of Police, (such approbation to  be given in writing) will be guilty of a misdemeanor.  Sec. 19. Every officer, policeman and commissary of market will be furnished with a copy of  the " Rules and Regulations," which they must  frequently peruse so that they may become perfectly acquainted with their several duties. They  must always have the same in their possession to  refer to in ease any doubt should arise in their  minds as to their authority for acting.  Sec. 20. Officers and Policemen must report  to their respective Lieutenants all suspicious persons and places, all bawdy houses, receiving shops,  disorderly houses of any kind, cabarets frequented  by negroes and slaves, gaming houses, and all  places where idlers, tipplers, gamblers, prostitutes,  and other disorderly and suspicious persons may  be in the habit of congregating.  Sec. 21. They must caution strangers and  others against going into places where idlers, tip- 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2651	2651	2652.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2652.jp2
page 14																										14  piers, gamblers, and other disorderly --uspicious  persons congregate; and against pickpockets,  droppers, mock-auctioneers, and all other vicious  persons. They must also direct strangers and  others, who may need such direction, the nearest  and safest way to their places of destination, and '  when necessary cause them to be accompanied to  their destination by one of the police ; but they  shall not, in any case, leave their beats for that  purpose, but will pass such persons from one beat  to another.  Sec. 22. Sergeants and Policemen who find  horses and cattle astray, must report the same to  the officer on duty at the Station House, who will  cause the same tcNje taken to the public pound.  Sec. 23. It shall be the duty of the Lieutenants of the respective Districts to report all violations of the Rules, Regulations or Orders, to the  Chief of Police.  Sec. 24. When a person is brought to the  Station House, accused of having committed a  felony or misdemeanor, the officer on duty to  whom the complaint is made, is only to ascertain  from the person preferring it that the act charged  constitutes a felony, or other offence, (as the case  may be) for which a prisoner can be detained, and 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2652	2652	2653.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2653.jp2
page 15																										15  that there is reasonable ground for the complaint  against the party accused. He will then enter the  name of the prisoner and the name and address of  the complainant and witnesses, and take the .necessary measures to insure their appearance before  the Recorder in the morning, and it shall be the  duty of the policeman making an arrest to appear  before the Recorder of the District and make the  necessary affidavit, and any policeman failing to  comply with this  provision, shall be   liable to be  Sec. 25. Every member will be immediately  dismissed from office, in addition to any other  punishment to which he may by law* be subject,  against whom any of the foliating charges shall  be substantiated:—  Disobedience of Orders. POLICEMEN.  Sec. 1. In the organization of the Police, the  first object in view is the prevention of crime, and  hence the exertions of Policemen must be constantly used to accomplish that end. To this effect  they must examine and make themselves perfectly  acquainted with every part of their beat, and vigilantly watch every description of person passing  their way, so as to acquire a faculty in observing  as well as in detecting offenders.  Sec. 2. Each Policeman^ must, to the utmost  of his power, prevent the commission of assaults,  breaches of the peace, and all other crimes about  to be.committed.  Sec. 3. He must by his vigilance render it extremely difficult for any one to commit crime on 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2664	2664	2665.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2665.jp2
page 27																										his beat—(the absence of crime will be considered  the best proof of the efficiency of the Police)—and  when in any district or beat offences frequently  occur, there will be good reason to suppose that  theire is negligence or want of ability on the part  of the person in charge of said beat.  Sec. 4. He must acquire such a knowledge of  the inhabitants within his beat as to enable him  at once to recognize them.  Sec. 5. He shall inspect every part of his beat  at least qnce in every twenty minutes, in order  that any person requiring assistance may be enabled to find him by remaining in one place. The  regularity of inspection thus enjoined, shall not  prevent his removing to any "particular place, if  his presence be required; but he will satisfy his  superior officer that there was sufficient cause for  such apparent neglect. The Police Officers of the City of New  Orleans are authorized to take cognizance of all  criminal offences, and violations of Ordinances,  committed within the following boundaries : Commencing at the Upper Line of the Fourth District,  known as the late City of Lafayette, and extending thence to the Lower Boundary of the Third  District, on the line known as the " Canal des  Pecheurs," and all the territory between that  space comprised within the limits of the Mississippi River,  and  the  Shipping and  Steamboats 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2671	2671	2672.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2672.jp2
page 34																										moored to the Whai  Pontehartrain.  ARRESTS.  Sec. 2. An arrest in criminal cases is the ap-  prehenr^H or d( taining a person to answer to a  crime or offence alleged against him, or of whieh   |  he is suspected to be guilty.   To this arrest all persons, without distinction, are liable, when accused |  of having committed a criminal offence.  Sec. 3. An arrest on a criminal charge may be  made in any place or at any time, on Sunday as  well as any other day, and in the night as well as  in the day time. But it must be borne in mind I  that, in all cases in which it is stated in these  structions that a police officer may arrest without  a warrant, it is necessary that he should witi  the commission of the offence, except the contrary  be stated in these instructions.  Sec. 4. The party arrested should be notified  of the officer's authority; and this will often pre-  vent resistance, by taking away the prospect of i  justifying or extenuating it.  Sec. 5. If an officer find his personal efforts  insufficient to effect an arrest, or if he have ret 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2672	2672	2673.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2673.jp2
PoliceRegulations1856-038-page 35																										Eo apprehend that resistance will be made, he  Ought to require all persons present, or as many  as he may think proper, to assist him; and all  who willfully disobey such command of assistance,  are guilty of misdemeanor.  Sec. 6. A person who has committed a felony,  or who, for reasonable cause is suspected of having committed a felony may, if he be immeolately  pursued, be followed wherever he may go; and  if he take refuge in any house, the officer or policeman, after stating his office and object, may, if  permission to enter shall not be given, break open  the outer door or windows, enter the house and  arrest the offender. If the police officer find the  outer door open, or if it be opened to him from  within, and he enters that way, he may break open  any inner door, after proper demand and refusal,  if necessary to make an arrest. It may be proper  to remark that, in general, a man's own Eouse is  regarded as his castle of defence, which is only to  be violated when absolute necessity compels the  disregard of smaller rights, in order to secure public benefit; so, when a felony has been committed  or a dangerous wound given, tEe party's house is  I no sanctuary for crime, and the doors may be 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2673	2673	2674.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2674.jp2
page 36																										forced after due notification, demand and refusal. ]  In all cases where doors may be broken open, ■  make an arrest, there must be a previous notification of the business and demand to enter, on  side, and refusal on the other, before proceei  to extremities. But though a felony has been c  mitted, yet a bare suspicion of guilt against the I  party will not authorize a breaking open of doors, I  in order to apprehend him, unless armed by a  rant.  Sec. 7. Persons under arrest must be dealt with  properly in all cases. It is the duty of a Police  Officer to keep prisoners safely, but he has no rightf  to punish them, and he must not even use language)  to them calculated to provoke or offend them, for I  such conduct would create a resistance on the part  of the prisoners, and a hostile feeling among bystanders towards the Police.  FELONIES.  Sec. 8. Felonies are offences for which the of]  fender, on conviction, shall be liable by law to be  punished with death, or by imprisonment in the)  Penitentiary. It is not intended to describe all  cases of felony, but the following are some iul 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2674	2674	2675.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2675.jp2
page 37																										37  which Police Officers or Policemen will be most  likely to be required to act without a warrant  from a Magistrate : Murder, manslaughter, rape,  mayhem or maiming, assault and battery with  tent to kill,  arson, burglary, negro stealing,  veigling a slave, harboring or concealing a slave,  employing seditious language to slaves, robbery,  larceny, receiving stolen goods, forgery, knowingly  passing counterfeit coin or bank bills, or having  them in possession with intent to pass them, swindling, perjury, forcibly rescuing a prisoner held in  legal custody upon any criminal charge.  POWER TO PREVENT FELONIES.  Sec. 9. It is the first duty of a Police Officer or  Policeman to prevent the commission of a crime,  and for this purpose he has power to arrest any  person who, from his acts, conduct, situation and  character, he has just cause to suspect is about to  commit a felony. He should" arrest any person  having in his possession any implements used for  or adapted to house breaking, under such circumstances as give just cause to suspect that he is  about to use them for that purpose; or any person 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2675	2675	2676.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2676.jp2
page 38																										38  who, in the presence of the police officer or policeman, may threaten the life of any person, or to  burn his house, or to commit any felony, or any  person armed with any offensive weapon, with intent therewith to commit a felony. He should  also arrest any persqn found in any building,  whether inhabited or not, or in any yard or garden,  under such circumstances as give just cause to  suspect that he is there with any felonious purpose.  In these, and similar cases, Police Officers must  judge from all the circumstances of the case, what  the intention of the party is. In some cases,  doubt can exist—as when the party is a notorious  thief, or acting with those who are known ti  thieves; or when the party is attempting to break  into a house, or is examining the doors and windows, or endeavoring to take property secretly.  If the intention of the party admits of doubt, the  Police Officer will not act hastily, but will closely  watch tho suspected party, that he may discover  his design.  POWER TO  ARREST   FOR   FELONY.  Sec  10. A Police Officer must make every exertion to effect the arrest of any one he may see 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2676	2676	2677.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2677.jp2
page 39																										39  the act of committing a felony, or any one  trged positively by another with having commit-  a felony, or even charged on the suspicion of  ither of having committed a felony, if the sus-  ion appear to the Police Officer to be well found-  and provided the person so suspecting go with  1.    And though no charge be made, yet if the  'ice/Officer have good cause to suspect a person  has committed a felony, he should arrest him; and  if he have reasonable grounds for his suspicions,  and the arrest is made discreetly and fairly, in pursuit of an offender, and not from any malice or ill  will, the Police Officer will be justified, even though  it should subsequently appear that no felony was  committed.    But the Police Officer must be cautious in such cases, as his sole defence can rest  only on the reasonableness of his suspicions.—See  Section 6 of this Article.  Sec. 11. If a Police Officer see any one carrying or in any manner conveying any goods, under  circumstances which lead to a strong suspicion  that they have been stolen, he should, particularly  in the night, stop and examine the person, and if  the appearance and manner of the party, his account of himself, and of the goods, and all the 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2677	2677	2678.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2678.jp2
page 40																										40  circumstances of the case should leave no doubt  that the goods have been stolen, he should arrest  the person and take possession of the goods. But  if the suspicion of the Police Officer be slight, he  should not stop the person, but watch him to disi  cover where the goods may be deposited, and if hei  then become fully convinced that the property has  been stolen, he will make the arrest and take  charge of the goods.  MISDEMEANOR,  DISORDERLY  CONDUCT, ETC.  Sec. 12. A misdemeanor is .any crime less thai  a felony; and if the offence be committed i  presence of a police officer, he may arrest the  der forthwith, or may in immediate pursuit follow  him as stated in Section 6 of this Article,  offences embraced in this class are so num  that but a small portion can be alluded to here  The following are supposed to be the most likely  to come under the observation of police officer! •  while in the discharge of their ordinary duties;  Riot and encouraging rioters, assault and battery,"  breach of the peace,  indecent  exposure   of one'i 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2678	2678	2679.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2679.jp2
page 41																										41  person to public view, or exposing to public view  any obscene print or book or indecent exhibition,  gambling or betting with free negroes, mulattoes  or slaves ; buying, selling or receiving of, to or  from any slave or slaves any produce or commodity  whatsoever without the consent in writing of the  master, owner, overseer or employer of such slave  or slaves; maliciously and cruelly beating or torturing any horse or mule.  Sec. 13. When a breach of the peace is likely  to take place, as when persons are openly preparing to fight, the police officer should give notice  of his office and immediately interfere to separate  the parties and to prevent others from joining in  the affray. If the offenders do not immediately  desist, and the disturbance be of a serious nature,  he should take the parties into custody, securing  also the principal instigators of the tumult, and do  every thing in his power to restore quiet. And  if the parties flee into a house, and there fight and  disturb the public ^peace, the police officer should  enter the house and arrest the offenders, and restore quiet, for it is the duty of police officers to  stop tumults  which  greatly  disturb the  public 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2679	2679	2680.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2680.jp2
page 42																										42  peace, whether they  occur in the streets  o:  buildings.—(See Section 6.)  Sec. 14. A police officer must be cautious  never to interfere idly or unnecessarily ; but when  required to act he will do so with discretion, decision and boldness; and he may arrest any one  who may oppose him in the execution of his duty,  if he can prove any specific act, but not otherwise.  Sec. 15. A police officer is not authorized to  assist in arresting without a warrant, a party  charged with disorderly conduct, or an assault, or  similar offence, not committed in his presence; nor  should he receive into his custody a person s  charged, unless the party has been arrested by a  person who saw the offence committed.  VAGRANTS.  Sec. 16. It is the duty of every Police 0:  or Policeman to arrest and convey before the Recorders of their respective districts, or to the Po?  lice? Station House, as the case may be, habitual  drunkards who are destitute and without visible j  means of support; common prostitutes who have j  no lawful employment whereby to maintain them- 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2680	2680	2681.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2681.jp2
page 43																										43  selves; able-bodied and sturdy beggars who may  apply for alms or solicit charity; children who  shall be found begging for alms, or soliciting alms  in any street, highway or public place; persons  wandering abroad begging, or who go about from  door to door, or place themselves in the streets,  highways, passages, or other public places, to beg  and receive alms.  INTOXICATION.  Sec. 17. Police Officers or Policemen must arrest any person they may find intoxicated, under  such circumstances as amount to a violation of  public decency.  LOST CHILDREN.  Sec. 18. Lost children wandering in the streets •  will be taken charge of by the Policemen on whose  beats or station the children may be found ; and  if their places of residence are ascertained, will be  immediately taken home by the Policeman finding  them, and if their homes are not ascertained will  be taken to one of the Police Station Houses;  and if they are not restored  to their parents or 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2681	2681	2682.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2682.jp2
page 44																										guardians by 10 o'clock the  following  morning,  they will be conveyed to the office of the   Mayor.  VIOLENT OR SUDDEN DEATH, ACCIDENTS, ETC.  Sec. 19. In case a Police Officer or Policeman  finds a person dead, he will immediately cause information of the event to be communicated to the  Coroner and the relatives or friends of the deceased ; he will prevent unnecessary exposure of  the body, and shall not move it from the place  where it was found, except in case of absolute necessity.  Sec. 20. If he should find a person dying or  seriously injured, he will send immediately for a  physician or convey the person home with all possible care and speed, or if nearest, and in any way  desirable, will convey him to the hospital or to the  Police Station House.  If the person be dying in consequence of injuries or violence, the public officer will make every  exertion to arrest the offenders, and will immediately send for the Recorder of the District or any  Justice of the Peace who may reside in the vicini- 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2682	2682	2683.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2683.jp2
page 45																										ty, to take the dying declaration of the person, or  to give such directions in the premises as he may  consider necessary.  Sec. 21. In case of an alarm of fire, the police  officers who arrive first at the scene of conflagration, must be particular to note the exact location  of the fire, and must examine minutely to ascertain  if there is any appearance of the house, store or  out-house having been set on fire by design. They  must note on their memorandum books the situation and place of particular kinis of goods, and  every thing that they may observe that could be of  service, in case the origin of the fire should become  a matter of legal investigation.  Sec. 22. Whenever any fire shall happen in  the night, the policemen shall give notice to each  of the firemen and policemen who may be at their  homes within their respective beats ; and they shall  also give the alarm by crying " Fire," and by  springing their rattles.  Sec. 23. The policemen will endeavor to clear  the streets from crowds and obstructions, so that  there shall be sufficient space for the firemen to  perform their duties, and a place for the deposit  of property saved. 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2683	2683	2684.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2684.jp2
page 46																										46  Sec. 24. The Lieutenant of the District in which  the fire maybe, will, until the arrival of the Chief  of Police, give directions to the Lieutenants of other  Districts, who may be present with their men, as to  the position they shall take with their men ; and  the Lieutenants of other Districts will report themselves to the Lieutenant of the District in which  the fire may be.  RIOTS.  Sec. 25. In case of riot, or any disturbance re-,  quiring a large force, the policemen on the beat or  station will immediately give notice to the officer  in charge at the Police Station House; who will  without delay and as secretly as possible proceed  with his men to the spot.  Sec. 26. If he have any doubt of his ability to  restore order or preserve the peace, he will immediately send notice to Lieutenants of other Districts  and to the Chief of Police.  Sec. 27. The policemen under the direction of  their proper officers will use every exertion to restore order, and disperse the persons assembled, but  if the rioters do not desist, the policemen must ar- 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2684	2684	2685.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2685.jp2
page 47																										47  rest as many of them as they can, particularly the  principal men; and if moderate means will not  cause the persons to disperse they must be driven  away or arrested. Such occasions require the exercise cf great coolness and firmness; force must  not be resorted to until it becomes absolutely necessary, but when necessary must be exercised to the  degree required, and the men must act in such a  manner as to make it apparent that they are determined to do their whole duty, and nothing but their  duty.  Sec. 28. To a riot there must be three or more  persons, and all persons who encourage, promote,  or take part in riots, whether by words, signs or  gestures, or by receiving the badges or insignia of  the rioters, are considered rioters, for in this case  all are principal. 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2685	2685	2686.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2686.jp2
