IL  command for this formation is given, the detachments halt at once on  the ground which their horses are to occupy in battery.  COMPOSITION OF THE BATTERY OF MANCEUVRE.  The Battery of manceuvre is composed of six field pieces and six  caissons, properly manned, horsed, and equipped. It is sometimes  reduced to four or increased to eight pieces. The tactics is adapted  to either number, but six pieces are supposed.  Each carriage is drawn by four or six horses, and the officers and  men are as follows:  One captain, who commands the battery.  Three lieutenants, each commanding a section; the section of the  junior lieutenant should be in the centre.  One lieutenant commanding the line of caissons.  When half batteries are formed, they are commanded by the two  lieutenants highest in rank.  Six mounted sergeants, each charged with guiding and superintending a piece.  Twenty-four, or thirty-sis drivers, being one to each pair of horses.  Six detachments of cannoneers, each containing nine men in mounted batteries, and eleven in horse batteries. This number includes  two corporals, one of whom is chief of the caisson; and the other  the gunner, has charge of the gun and its detachment. In each de-  . tachment of horse artillery two of the cannoneers are horse holders.  Two trumpeters or buglers.  One guidon.  The battery is divided into three sections, denominated the right,  left, and centre sections. Should there be four sections, they are denominated the right, right-centre, left-centre, and left sections. A  section contains two pieces and two caissons, and in each section  the pieces are denominated right piece and left piece.  The battery is also divided into half batteries, denominated right  half battery, and left half battery.  The word piece applies to the gun or howitzer, either with or without its limber; and sometimes to the piece and caisson together.  The front of a battery, in the order in battery, is the front of the  lino of pieces. Iu all other formations it is the front of the first line  of drivers.  The right or left of a battery is always that of the actual front,  whether the pieces or caissons lead.  The interval is a space measured parallel to the front.  The distance is a space measured in depth, or perpendicular to  the front.  The measures of intervals and distances are given in yards, and  express the vacant spaces between the component parts of the  battery.  _ The object of a right or left wheel is to give the carriage a direction perpendicular to the one it had before. Grape one-third the diameter of the ball has sal  ficient velocity at 880 yards with Impounders, and 760 yards with  7-pounders, to disable men. When the distance is within 500 yards  the fire of grape is superior to that of ball against troops.  In howitzer practice the shells are fired with small charges, as they  break easily when they strike an obstacle with a great velocity. The '  point blaok of the howitzer varies with the charge. The greatest  range of the 21-pound howitzer is about 2200 yards; that of the 6-  inch about 2600 yards.  The chances of hitting a mark with a howitzer diminish with the  length of the bore, the calibre and weight of the shell. The deviations with small charges are nearly double those with heavy charges,  The shell of the howitzer produces no effect when fired against  masonry, as it invariably breaks. It imbeds itself in the earth and  wood, and bursting produces a considerable crater. The fragments  of the shell are often thrown to distances over 600 yards, and they  do great damage to objects near. The wounds from them are very  dangerous. The shells loaded with incendiary compositions are used  to fire buildings. The rate of firing- for field guns is from 35 to 40  seconds for 6-potmders, and one minute for J2-pounders. But when  the enemy ie close at hand, and deliberate aim not necessary, two  rounds may be fired per minute.  2.—SELECTIONS OF POSITIONS FOR FIELD BATTERIES.  The position taken up on the field for a battery must be looked at  in a double point of view—first, as to its suitableness for annoying  the enemy; and second, as to its being favorable for limiting the effects of the enemy's fire aimed at the battery.  As a general rule artillery should overlook all the ground over  which an enemy might advance, the pieces of heavi st calibre being  placed on the most commanding points. The batteries, however,  should not be within musket range of woods, or of any ground where  the enemy's sharpshooters might find cover to annoy them. The  slope of the ground on which the gun rests must not be too oblique  to the line of fire, otherwise tho shot will not tell ; the declivity of  the ground should never exceed one perpendicular to filteen base.  When the ground between the battery and the enemy is horizontal  and firm, it will be best to take a position near the enemy, as the  ricochet shots on such ground do not rise much. If the ground is  uneven a distant position may be more favorable to obtain a grazing  tire. Positions should be so chosen that hollows, woods, villages,  &C-, on the front or flank of the line occupied by the troops may be  thoroughly swept, to prevent the enemy's column from approaching  under cover.  Advantage should be taken of any unevenness of ground to place  the artillery under cover until called into action. But all broken  ground occupied by batteries should be thoroughly examined, and  tbe avenues leading to it by which the enemy's cavalry might fall  upon the batteries, should be obstructed.  Stony ground is a bad position for a battery, owing to the effects 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2784	2784	2785.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2785.jp2
MilitaryManual-1861-079-Page 75																										INSTRUCTION   F0K  FIELD   ARTILLERY. T»  of the enemy's shot in scattering the stones. Very even ground is  unfavorable, as well as uneven ground which opens in funnel shape  outwards from the battery, as the enemy is enabled in either case to  concentrate his fire from an extended front upon tho battery. Rough  ground breaks the effects of the enemy's ricochet shots, and when it  presents bluffs or perpendicular faces towards the enemy, it will stop  the balls that strike those parts. Undulating ground hinders the  enemy from observing the effects of his fire. If the ground in rear  of the battery is hidden, the enemy will generally aim too high; but  if tho battery is relieved against the sky it will assist his aim. It  must be borne in mind, that in taking advantage of undulation to  cover a battery, it will not do to fire behind the covering ridge, as  the aim and range will be rendered very uncertain. Batteries should  never be placed directly in front of other troops, since they nccessa--  rily attract the enemy's fire to them, and would therefore cause great  damage to the troops in rear.  3.—MANAGEMENT OF THE  FIRE OF BATTERIES.  The management of the fire with regard to the projectile to b^  used is very irauortant. It has been observed that the ball and  howitx produce a greater moral effect upon troops than grape.  When it is taken into consideration that a six pounder shot will take  off twenty-four ranks at a distance of 500 to 600 yards, the tremendous effect of a smashing fire of ball upon a column may be readily  understood.  A fire of balls or shells should, therefore, be opened upon troops at  a distance, when they arc in mass, in several lines, or when an  enemy's line can be enfiladed. When an enemy's column is advancing, a lire of shell should be opened on the head of the column; and,  if it be in retreat, the aim should bo directed on the centre. The fire  of shells is good against cavalry, as their explosion produce great  disorder.  A fire of grape or canister should be opened on troops in line, or  in open order, but not at distances greater than 000 or 800 yards.  In an attack upon troops in line, a battery may advance to within 4O0  or 500 yards before opening ils fire of grape, and even nearer if the  ground is unfavorable to ricochet, and there is but little danger from  an attack of the enemy's skirmishers on the flanks of the battery.  When an enemy's battery advances nearer than point blank range, a  fire of grape should be opened upon it, just at the moment when,  having commenced the movement to place the pieces in battery, the  flanks of the horses will be offered to the fire.  As a general rule, the aim should be rather low, as ricochet shots  produce considerable moral effect. For this purpose, when the  ground is favorable to this fire, the aim should be at the mark, but  rather under it, for distances within 1200 yards; beyond this, and up  to 1800 yards, when this fire becomes inefficacious, the piece may be  fired with an elevation of one degree between its axis and the ground.  The pieces of the battery should be separated at wide intervals,  when the position will admit of it, to offer fewer chances to the divergence of the enemy's shot; but the  fire should be concentrated on 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2785	2785	2786.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2786.jp2

POSITION"   OF   RATFF.WES   IN ATTACKING   AND   DEFENDING IN'TRENCHIIENTS,  In the attack of intrenched positions, the batteries should -be placed  to obtain enfilading views on the enemy's lines, and a fire be opened  with ball and shells from pieces of the heaviest calibre.     When one  column of attack has arrived near the works, the batteries should bo  ' so posted as to support it if repulsed.  In the defence of works, the piece should be so placed as to cross  their fire upon the ground over which the enemy must, approach. The  heaviest pieces should be placed on the most secure points, and in  such positions that their fire may not incommode the ti'"ops defending the work. The light guns should be placed at ihe advanced  points, as they can be most easily withdrawn. The howitzers should  occupy points from which hollows, woods, &c, in advance of thrjal  works, can bo reached by the shells.  5.—EFFECTS, ETC., OF BATTERIES   FOI; HABB0B DEFENCE. As the object of all defensive arrangements—whether artificial  objects be raised or the natural features only of a position be seized  upon for the purpose—is to place troops under cover from the enemy's  lire, and to enable them to deliver their own with effect, some knowl-  edge of the chances of hitting a mark of given dimensions at various distances, as well as the influences which the "undulations and  character of the ground, and the physical and mental state of the  party firing, may have upon their aim, are essential elements in estimating the advantages which they present, the object of this is to  present, from the most recent and authentic sources, some of the  facts arrived at by experiment which bear on the question.  There is no fact more striking than the groat disproportion between the numbers of combatants put hors de cmhat and the  amount of ammunition expended even in the most bloody engagements.    Hundreds of instances might be cited in support of this.  Military writers estimate that not more than one ball out of ten  thousand attains its mark ; and it is estimated, for example, that in  the expedition of the French to Algiers, in 1830, which lasted but  fifteen days, upwards of three millions of cartridges were expended.  Ths causes of this disproportionate application of means to an end,  may be found partly in a careless use of his ammunition by the  soldier ; partly in the want of good instruction and frequent prac- 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2787	2787	2788.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2788.jp2
MilitaryManual-1861-082-Page 78																										i8 TARGET  PRACTICE   OF  SMALL  ARMS.  tice, particularly in those men who have not been familiar witl  use ot fire-arms from their youth ; partly in the haste with which a  lire against an enemy is delivered, which destroys calmness and good  order, and impairs the aim ; but chiefly by the over-estimation of the  distance caused by fear, smoke, or the movable character of the  mark. Much depends upon the attention paid by the officer to his  duties to prevent this.  The men should be frequently practiced at target-firing, and be  taught to note the influence which the firmness with which the pieces  is pressed against the shoulder, its depression or elevation according  to the distance of the target, and the character of the ground, both  as to the hardness of its surface and its undulations, have upon the  accuracy of the aim. This practice should not be confined to the  open field, but be also extended to the various positions in which  soldiers may be placed behind breastworks and other shelters, such  as pallisades, loopholed walls, abattis arranged for defence, &c, iu  order that the soldier may feel himself at home under all circumstances, and not be called upon to cast about for the best way of  managing his piece in every new emergency. So far from urging  the men to load and fire rapidly, every pains should be taken by the  officers to impress upon them the necessity of not hurrying, of keeping perfectly cool, of loading steadily, and aiming deliberately.—  Volley firing is admirable practice for this purpose ; that by files is  apt to give a slovenly and hurried action to the soldier.  The fire of troops in line should be kept, as far as possible, under  the control of the officer. His position and means of estimating  distance enable him far better judge of the proper moment than the  men generally can. It is generally admitted that not more than four  or five rounds can be fired in two minutes, allowing the men time to  aim deliberately ; three may be fired in one minute, but at the ex*  pense of a good aim.  As all infantry arc now instructed as well in the duties of skirmishers as in the ordinary service of the line, they should be prac  tised at firing both at a small mark, like the ordinary round target,  and at a large square, with black bauds made across it, showing the  ordinary height of the knees, centre of the body, the breast, shoulders, head and top of the cap.  As the point blank of the musket, fired with the bayonet off, is at  about 120 to 130 yards, to attain a point at this distance it must be  directly aimed at ; what it is at a distance short of this the aim must  be below it; and when at one over this, the aim must be above it.-*  With the bayonet fixed the musket has no point blank, and to hit a  point the aim must always be above it. The following rules for aiming are given by Robert, a recent French author of high standing,  in a work on artillery, as drawn from the practice of the French :  To hit the centre of the body, at all distances, up to 110 yards,  with hayamt fixed, aim at the breast.  To hit the same point from 110 to 150 yards distance, aiinat the  shoulders.  To hit tho same point fiom 150 to 200 yards distance, aim oXthshead,  To hit the same point from 200 to 220 yards distance, aim at the  top of the cap, 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2788	2788	2789.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2789.jp2

II.—PROBABLE EFFECT OF SMALL ARMS,  Beyond 220 yards$ the effect of the fire is very uncertain. Beyond  451) yards, the bail seldom gives a dangerous wound, although the  musket fired under an elevation of 4 or 5 degrees will carry from  600 to 700 yards, and under greater elevations over 1000 yards.  The nature of the surface of the ground, as has already been  stated, has considerable influence upon the efficacy of the fire. lit  broken or ploughed ground, fire is less effective than on an even,  linn surface, since in the former the balls that strike if are embedded,  whereas in the latter they ricochet, and thus attain their mark; it  being estimated that, under favorable circumstances, about oue-  geventh of the balls produce their effect in this way. MilitaryManual-1861-085-Page 81																										HARDKE 3 MANUAL OF ARMS.  LESSON   II.  MANUAL   OP  ARMS.  The Manual of Anns will be taught to four men, placed, at first, in  one rank, elbow to elbow, and afterwards in two ranks.  Each command will be executed in one time (or pause,) but this  time will be divided into motions, the better to make known the mechanism.  The rate (or swiftness) of each motion in the manual of arms, with  the exceptions herein indicated, is fixed at the ninetieth part of a  minute ; but, in order not to fatigue the attention, the instructor will,  at first, look more particularly to the execution of the motions, without requiring a nice observance of the cadence, to which he will bring  the recruits progressively, and after they shall have become a little  familiarized with the handling of the piece.  As the motions relative to the cartridge, the rammer, and to the fixing and unfixing of the bayonet, cannot be executed at the rate proscribed, nor even with a uniform swiftness, they will not be subjected  to that cadence. The instructor will, however, labor to cause these  motions to be executed with promptness, and, above all, with regularity.  The last syllable of the command will decide the brisk execution of  the first motion of each time (or pause.) The commands, two, three,  and four will decide the brisk execution of the other motions. As  soon as the recruits shall well comprehend the positions of the several  motions of a time, they will be taught to execute the time without  resting on its different motions ; the mechanism of the time will nevertheless be observed, as well to give a perfect use of the piece, as to  avoid the sinking of, or slurring over, either of the  motions.  The manual of arms will be taught in the following progression :  The instructor will command :  Support—Arms .  (One time anil three motions.)  1st motion. Turn the piece with the right hand, the  barrel to the front ; carry the piece to the left shoulder, and pass the fore-arm extended on the breast  between the right hand and the cock; support the  cock against the left fore-arm, the left hand resting  on the right breast.  Zd motion. Drop the right hand by the side. 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2791	2791	2792.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2792.jp2

The manual of ai'ms frequently   distorts  the  persons of recruits  they acquire ease   ami   confidence in   the several positions.—  : struutor will therefore frequently recur to elementary principles  'othe course of the lessons.  Recruits are also extremely liable to curve the sides and hack, and  ange Un: shoulders, especially in   loading.    Consequently, the  'ostructor will not cause  them to "dwell too   long  at a time, in one  Position.  ** hen, after some days of exercise in the manual of arms,  the  °ut men shall be well established in their  use,   the  instructor will  Ways terminate the lesson by marching the   men   for some time in  rauk, and ;&gt;t one pace apart, in common and quick time, in order 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2801	2801	2802.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2802.jp2
MilitaryManual-1861-096-Page 92																										02 hardee's hantal of arms.  to confirm them more and more in the mechanism of the step j h&  will also teach them to rmirk time and to change step, which will be  executed in the following manner :  To mark time.  The four men marching in the direct step, the instructor will command :  1-. Mark time   2. MARCH.  At the second command, which will be given at the instant a foot-  is coming- to tho ground, the recruits will make a semblance of marching, by bringing the heels by the side of each other, and observing  the cadence of the step, by raising each foot alternately without advancing.   ■  The instructor wishing the direct step to be resumed, will command :  1-, Forward.   2. March.  At the second command, which will be given as prescribed above,  the recruits will retake the step of twenty-eight inches.  To change step.  The squad being in march, the instructor will command :■  1. Change step.   2- March.  At the second command, which will be given at the instant either  foot is coming to the ground, bring the foot which is in rear by th»  Hide of that which is in front, and step off again with the foot which  was in front.  To march backwards.  The instructor wishing the squad to march backwards, will command :  1. Squad backward.   2. March.  At the wecoud command, the recruits will step off smartly with  the left root fourteen inches to the rear, reckoning from heel to heel,  and so on with the feet in succession till the command halt, which  . will always bo preceded by the caution squad. The men will halt at  this command, and bring back the foot in front by the side of the  other.  This step will always be executed in quick time.  The instructor will be watchful that the recruits march straight  to the rear, and (hat the erect position of body and the piece be not  deranged.  Lesson III. The P.oard having under consideration  an Ordinance of  Convention, entitled,   "An Ordinance lo regulate the military system  of the State of Mississippi," made the following orders, to-wit:  [ZiTl (N.  1st. BEST MODE OF LOADING A S1TOT-GTO.  (By Capt. L. M. Bckfoot, of tin; Clie.sterfii'lu Mounted Rangers, Virginia.)  Cany your gun with you to the place where you intend to buy your  shot ; get a cut, wad, drive it down the barrel of the gun a quarter of  an inch, level and smooth.  Now take the shot and put three on the wad ; if they fill the bore  of the gun well, snug and smooth, without any loose space, they  will do. Yon will thus find that three shot can fill the circle of the  bore of the gun, so can four ; after four, the next number to fill the  circle, seven ; to shoot men with, these last will be two small : therefore, buy onlv such shot as will, on careful trial in ihe gun itself lay  -in tiers of either three or four.  I prefer, for any gun, tiers of three ; and in loading the double  gun to meet an enemy, put in a very lull charge ot powder, and  only two tiers of shot, so that they will lie snug and close iu the  gun, and the nix shots will be opfiut d on equally by the expansive  force of the powder, and will be projected from the muzzle of the  gun almost in a solid lump, and will remain within six or eight in*  dies &lt;f one another in a flight of seventy-five or eighty yards.—  "VVitli only two tiers of shot, almost any quantity of powder may be  put under them without risk of the gun. 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2819	2819	2820.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2820.jp2

MilitaryManual-1861-117-Page 113																										HIaLTH  HIHT8  FOR  YOLUKTBURS, US  , S. Abond'ant sleep is essential to bodily efficiency, and to that alertness of mind  which is all-important in an engagement; and few thing-* more certainly and more  ^^^actually prevent, sound sleep than eating heartily after auu down, especially  after a heavy in irch or desparale battle.  . 9. No hmg is mor« certain to secure endurance and capability of long-continued  effort, than ihe avoid,nee of everything as a drink except cold water, not excluding coffee at breakfast.    Drink as little as possible, of, even cold water.  , 10. Aftei any sort of exhausting effort, a cup of coffee, hot or cold, is an admirable sustainer uf the strength, until nature begins to recover herself.  11. Never eat heartily just before a great undertaking; because the nervous  power ia irresistibly drawn to the stomach to manage the food eaten, thus drawing off that supply which the brain and muscles so much need.  12. If persons wilt drink brandy, it is incomparably safer to do so after an effort  than before ; for it can give only a transient strength, lasting but a few minutes :  but at ileau never be known how long any given effort is to be kept in continuance,  and if longer than a few minutes, the body becomes more/feeble thin it would  have been without the stimulus, it is clear that its use before an effort is always  hazardous, and is always unwise.  13. Never go to sleep, especially after a great effort, even in hot weather, with-  ont some covering over you. i   ,  .14. Under all circumstances, rather than He down on the hare ground, lie in  the hollow of two logs placed together, or across several smaller pieces of woodt  laid side by side ; or sit.on your hat, leaning against a tree. A nap of ten or fifteen minutes in that position, will refresh you more than an hour on the bare earth,  with the additional advantage of perfect safety.  15. A cut is less dangerous than a bullet wound, and heala more rapidly,   ■  16. If from any wound the blood spirts out in jets, instead of a steady stream,  jpu will di« in a few minute- unless it is remedied ; because an artery has been  divided, and that takes the blood direct from the fountain of life. To stop this  instantly, tie a handkerchief or other cloth very closely between I ! the wound and  the heart; put a stick, bayonet, orr&lt;mrod between 'he skin aud the handkerchief,  and twist it around until the bleeding ceases, and keep it thus until the surgeon  arrives. .  17. If the blood flows in a slow, regular stream, a vein has been pierced, and  the handkerchief must be on the other side of the wound from the heart; that is,  btlow the wound. ,  18. A bullet through the abdomen (belly or stomach) is more certainly fatal  than if aimed at the head or heart; for in the latter cases the ball is often glanced  off by Ihe bone, or follows round it under the skin ; but when it enters the stomach  or bowels, from any direction, death is inevitable under all conceivable circumstances, but is scarcely ever instantaneous Generally the person lives a day or  two with perfect clearness of intellect, often not suffering greatly- The practical  bearing of this statement in reference to the great future is clear.  19. Let the whole beard grow, but not longer than some three inches. This  •lengthens and thickens its growth, and thus makes a more perfec" protection  for the lungs against, dmt, and of the throat against, winds android in winter,  while in the summer a greater perspiration of the skin is induced, with an increase  of evaporation ■, hence greater coolness of the parts on the outside, while the throat  tt less feverish, thirsty and dry.  20. Avoid fats and fat meats in summer, and in all warm days.  21. Whenever possible, take a plunge into any lake or running stream, every  morning as soon as you get up j if not at hand, endeavor to wash the body all  over as soon as you leave your bed, for personal cleanliness acts like a charm  "■gainst, at diseases, always either warding them off altogether, or greatly mitigating their severity aud shorieuing their duration.  22. Keep the hair of the bead closely cut, say within an inch and a half of the  scalp in every part, repeated on the first of each month, and wash the whole scalp  plentifully in cold water every looming.  23. Wear woolen stockings and moderately loose shoes, keeping the toe and fins'**"' nails always cut close.  34- It is more important, to wash the feet well every night, than to wash the face  •id hands of mornings ; because it aids to keep the skin and nails soft, and to pre.  ^•Qichafiogg, blisters and corns, til of which greatly interfere with a soldier's . 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2823	2823	2824.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2824.jp2

About—A technical word to express the movement by which a body of troops  cliiii'g'''" ',''"i front by word of command.  | Ari'iy &lt;'orps—A divMut: of tile army organized for a campaign, composed of infant y. cavalry and artillery. The backbone of ar. army \.&lt; the infantry, which is  Bo!i e inn s divided into light aud heacy infantry. Four-fifths of an army should bo  COii!|i 'S&gt;'d oi infantry.  Battaltor.—A body of infantry, of two or more companies, under one commander.  A colonel may divide bis regiment into several pints, assigning separate commands  to stil' r inate officers, and each part would a ■ a battalion.  Brig'dc— Two or lucre regiments—commanded by a Brigadier-General.  Buttery—When a number of field pieces of artillery are arranged together they  constitute a battery. A battery of field artillery is usually composed ot sis pieces.  The cannon are six-pound brass pieces, or twelve-pound howitzers.  Company—A company consists of one captain, one 1st lieutenant, two 2d lieutenants, four sergeants, four corporals, two musicians and ninety privates.  Countermarch—A change by wings, companies, platoons, sections or flies, whereby those ou the light take up the ground take up the ground uiig'nally occupied by  the left; generally used in changing the front.  Deploy—To display, tft spread out: a column issai.l to deploy when the divisions  Open nut, nr extond to form the line on some one of those divisions-  Btjile —Is to reduce divisions or  platuons  into a small front, in order to march  through a defile;  which is most conveniently done by quarter facing to either the  Tight or the left, and then covering to either right or left, and marching through by  :  filBs, etc.  Dnss—Tn dress, is to keep the body in such a relative position as to contribute  toward and form a part of, an exact continuity of the Line, upon whatever trout, or  in whatever shape the battalion may be formed.  Division—Two or more brigades  Facings.—Are the different movements of a battalion or of any other body of men,  to the right, left, light or left about.  Field Officers—Colonels, Lieutenant-Colonels and Majors are so called.  File—A line of soldiers drawn up behind one another-    As a general term a file  means two soldiers, the front and rear rank men.   Every soldier of infantry covers  asp-ice of twenty-one inches.  Flank—The- extreme right or left of an army of encampment.  Guides—i\ en employed to direct the. march of a company or battalion.  Interval— Any space between.    A word variously applied in military dispositions  and manoeuvres, to denote any given distance or'space.    The interval between two  battaii ns is  the space that separates them when thi-y are drawn up in action, or  wlien encamped ; it is generally wide enough to admit the march of another battal-  lion, tuat is to say. it is equal to the extent of its front when in line.  Line, or Line if Battle—Is the arrangement or disposition of an army for battle;  '   its front being extended in a straight line as far as the ground will pern.it, in order  that the seveial corps of cavalry and infantry which eotnpose it may not be cut off  or flanked by tho enemy.    European armies are usually drawn up in three lines ;  first being named the tan, the second the main body, and the third is called the rear  guard.  Orderlies and Orderly Sergeants are appointed to wait hpon the general and ether  officers, to communicate orders and cany messages. On bearing the drum beat for  orders, Orderlies are to repair to the Orderly Room, and having taken down$he  Orders iu writing, they are immediately to show them to the officers of their com-  ■Panv, and to warn the men for duty.  Phot—ls the officer or soldiers who happens to be at the flank on which a company wheels  Regiment— A regiment consists of ten companies—the officers being a Colonel,  Lieutenant-Colonel, Major, Adjutant, Quarter-Master, Paymaster The Colonel  cotnuiutuis. Tue Lieutenant-Colonel has charge of the right wing, aud the .Major  me left v.-ing The Adjutant communicates orders, forms ihe regiments lor drill,  parade, etc., and acts as an assistant to the lieutenant-colonel. The Quartermaster  «s charge of the camp, equipage, clothing, etc., ot the regiment.  Squadron—A budy of Cavalry of two or more Companies. Each squadron is  .•Ouipoeed offour platoons; two platoons form a division. 		2012-01-18	2012-01-18	http://cdm16313.contentdm.oclc.org:80/cdm/ref/collection/p15140coll10/id/2825	2825	2826.jp2	/p15140coll10/image/2826.jp2

Page 23																										HEROIC WOMEN OF THE SOUTH;  MADAME ANN D. W. SPLANE.  These sketches which have for so many years been hidden  within the leaves of my diary have, some of them, been transferred to the I .trior Magazine", and, as they were  received with  thought fit to continue them.  There are very many women of the South who have braved  chivalrous deeds deserve a high place in the standard of fame.  These have lived and died, in a pioneer country, unhonored and  unsung, and from the oral traditions of family lore, I have collected much of tho history of several characters.  The lady whose name heads this article was born in Richmond  county, Georgia, and educated in the city of Augusta. Her  maiden name was Douglas, and she is connected with a numerous  and respectable family in that State. E. John Ellis diary, 1865 February-March (vol. 1)	Ellis, Ezekiel John, 1840-1889.; Johnson Island Prison.; Prisoners of war--Ohio.; Missionary Ridge, Battle of, Tenn., 1863--Personal narratives, Confederate.; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Causes.; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Campaigns.; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Prisoners and prisons.	Volume one of Ezekiel John Ellis' diary (February-March 1865) begins with a retrospective account by Ellis of the events leading up to the Civil War and his service in the war before his capture and imprisonment at Johnson Island in 1863. This portion of the volume is entitled A Retrospect (p. 1-72), wherein he describes his political views; the development of Confederate military forces; his military service; battles in Mississippi, Georgia, Kentucky, and Tennessee; and his capture at the Battle of Missionary Ridge. Ellis wrote the account while imprisoned at Johnson Island Prison in Ohio. It serves as an introduction to his prison diary, which begins February 1, 1865. In the diary, Ellis documents his daily observations and experiences as a prisoner of war.  During his imprisonment, he read a great deal, and his entries exhibit an extensive knowledge of history and an appreciation of poetry. Additionally, his personal thoughts reflect his grief and distress over the war. Pages 118-132 contain poems by and autographs of other prisoners.  Page 131 also contains a list of men killed and where.  Includes transcript of diary entries (C:97, box 1, folder 1).	Ellis, Ezekiel John, 1840-1889.			1865	diary	Louisiana State University Libraries, Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special ).	E. John Ellis Diary, Mss. 2795	http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special/findaid/2795.inv.pdf	Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Civil War: Context & Conflict	en	military, prisoner of war; writing, literature, and reading; justification for war; politics and elections; slavery; slaves; race relations and racial attitudes	E. John Ellis Diary, Mss. 2795, Louisiana and Lower Mississippi Valley Collections, LSU Libraries, Baton Rouge, La.	Ezekiel John Ellis, attorney and congressman, was born Oct. 15, 1840, in St. Tammany Parish, La., to Ezekiel Parke Ellis and Tabitha Warner Ellis. He received his early education in Covington and Clinton, La., and later attended Centenary College at Jackson, La., graduating in 1858. He studied law at the University of Louisiana in New Orleans (now Tulane University) obtaining his law degree in 1861. At the onset of the Civil War, he enlisted in the Confederate army as a first lieutenant and was later promoted to captain in the 16th Louisiana Infantry Regiment, Army of Tennessee. His regiment participated in the Confederate Heartland Offensive. He was sent to Johnson Island, Lake Erie, Ohio, after his capture at the Battle of Missionary Ridge in February of 1863. He remained a prisoner at Johnson Island for the duration of the war and was paroled in June of 1865. After the war he returned to Amite, where he served as editor to the Amite Daily Wanderer until 1866, and then moved to Covington to open a law practice. Ellis was an active member of the Democratic Party, serving in Louisiana State Senate (1866-1870) and the United States House of Representative (1875-1885). He also held the position of chairman of the Committee on Mississippi Levees and was a key figure in the Wormley House Conference that helped resolve the disputed election of 1876 in Louisiana. After leaving Congress, he resumed the practice of law in Washington, D.C., where he died April 25, 1889. William J. Minor diary, 1861-1865	Plantations--Louisiana--Management.; Plantation owners--Louisiana.; Plantation overseers--Louisiana.; Slaves--Louisiana.; Crops--Louisiana.	William J. Minor's diary is an outline of rules governing management of his plantations, including duties and restrictions on overseers (such as discipline of slaves), as well as details regarding cultivation of particular crops. Volume 33.	Minor, William J., 1807-1869.		1861-1865		diary	Louisiana State University Libraries, Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special ).	William J. Minor and Family Papers, Mss. 519, 594, 859	http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special/findaid/0519.pdf	Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Civil War: Context & Conflict	en	plantation management, racial attitudes	William J. Minor and Family Papers, Mss. 519, 594, 859, Louisiana and Lower Mississippi Valley Collections, LSU Libraries, Baton Rouge, La.	William J. Minor, son of Stephen Minor of Natchez, Mississippi, was a sugar planter of Southdown and Hollywood plantations in Terrebonne Parish and Waterloo Plantation in Ascension Parish, Louisiana. He was married to Rebecca A. Gustine and had eight children. William Minor was influential in the development of horse racing and thoroughbred breeding in Louisiana. The Minor family was related by marriage to the Kenner family of Louisiana. Robert M. Lusher diary, 1862	District courts--Confederate States of America.; District courts--Louisiana.; Taxation--Confederate States of America.; Taxation--Louisiana.	Lusher's 1862 diary includes daily activities in performance of duties as clerk of the Confederate States District Court and chief tax collector for Louisiana during the Civil War. Volume 4.	Lusher, Robert Mills, 1823-1890.			1862	diary	Louisiana State University Libraries, Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special ).	Robert M. Lusher Papers, Mss. 696, 788, 1025		Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright has expired and the item is therefore in the public domain.  Permission to reproduce this image must be requested through the Special Collections Division, Louisiana State University Libraries.	Civil War: Context & Conflict		Louisiana government, economics and markets	Robert M. Lusher Papers, Mss. 696, 788, 1025, etc., Louisiana and Lower Mississippi Valley Collections, LSU Libraries, Baton Rouge, La.	Robert M. Lusher served as clerk of the Confederate States District Court and chief tax collector for the Louisiana government during the Civil War. Prior to the war he taught in New Orleans, La., and was appointed by the city council to the board of directors of the New Orleans Public Schools. He held the position of Louisiana State Superintendent of Education in 1856 and again from 1876 to 1879. Together with Professor W. O. Rogers, he began publication of the Louisiana Journal of Education.	Gives insight into day to day work of a CSA bureaucrat.  I recommend the diary in its entirety. Robert M. Lusher diary, 1863	District courts--Confederate States of America.; District courts--Louisiana.; Taxation--Confederate States of America.; Taxation--Louisiana.	Lusher's 1863 diary includes daily activities in performance of duties as clerk of the Confederate States District Court and chief tax collector for Louisiana during the Civil War. Volume 5.	Lusher, Robert Mills, 1823-1890.			1863	diary	Louisiana State University Libraries, Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special ).	Robert M. Lusher Papers, Mss. 696, 788, 1025		Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright has expired and the item is therefore in the public domain. Civil War: Context & Conflict	en	Louisiana government, economics and markets	Robert M. Lusher Papers, Mss. 696, 788, 1025, etc., Louisiana and Lower Mississippi Valley Collections, LSU Libraries, Baton Rouge, La.	Robert M. Lusher served as clerk of the Confederate States District Court and chief tax collector for the Louisiana government during the Civil War. Prior to the war he taught in New Orleans, La., and was appointed by the city council to the board of directors of the New Orleans Public Schools. He held the position of Louisiana State Superintendent of Education in 1856 and again from 1876 to 1879. Together with Professor W. O. Rogers, he began publication of the Louisiana Journal of Education.	Gives insight into day to day work of a CSA bureaucrat.  I recommend the diary in its entirety. Robert M. Lusher diary, 1863-1864	District courts--Confederate States of America.; District courts--Louisiana.; Taxation--Confederate States of America.; Taxation--Louisiana.	Lusher's 1863-1864 diary includes daily activities in performance of duties as clerk of the Confederate States District Court and chief tax collector for Louisiana during the Civil War.	Lusher, Robert Mills, 1823-1890.			1863-1864	diary	Louisiana State University Libraries, Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special ).	Robert M. Lusher Papers, Mss. 696, 788, 1025		Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright has expired and the item is therefore in the public domain. Civil War: Context & Conflict	en	Louisiana government, economics and markets	Robert M. Lusher Papers, Mss. 696, 788, 1025, etc., Louisiana and Lower Mississippi Valley Collections, LSU Libraries, Baton Rouge, La.	Robert M. Lusher served as clerk of the Confederate States District Court and chief tax collector for the Louisiana government during the Civil War. Prior to the war he taught in New Orleans, La., and was appointed by the city council to the board of directors of the New Orleans Public Schools. He held the position of Louisiana State Superintendent of Education in 1856 and again from 1876 to 1879. Together with Professor W. O. Rogers, he began publication of the Louisiana Journal of Education.	Gives insight into day to day work of a CSA bureaucrat.  Volume 6. John Ellis diary, 1865 April-October (vol. 2)	Ellis, Ezekiel John, 1840-1889.; Johnson Island Prison.; Prisoners of war--Ohio.; Plantation owners--Louisiana--Fiction.; Secession--Southern States.; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Prisoners and prisons.; United States--Politics and government--1865-1869.	In volume two of Ezekiel John Ellis' diary (April-October 1865), Ellis documents his daily observations and experiences as a prisoner of war.  He considers the justification for war, the defeat of the Confederate States, and the political environment after the war. During his imprisonment, he read a great deal, and his entries exhibit an extensive knowledge of history and an appreciation of poetry.  He also describes his trip back to Louisiana after his release.  Page 1-57 are his diary of April-July 1865; pages 58-67 contain an incomplete work of fiction (Oct. 19, 1865) concerning a Louisiana planter at the onset of the Civil War; pages 200-217 contain speeches about secession made after the war; and pages 237-238 consist of poems "The Contraband" and "The Young Volunteer," which are identifiably by soldiers.  Includes transcript of diary entries (C:97, box 1, folder 1).	Ellis, Ezekiel John, 1840-1889.			1865	diary	Louisiana State University Libraries, Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special ).	E. John Ellis Diary, Mss. 2795	http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special/findaid/2795.inv.pdf	Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Civil War: Context & Conflict	en	military, prisoner of war; writing, literature, and reading	E. John Ellis Diary, Mss. 2795, Louisiana and Lower Mississippi Valley Collections, LSU Libraries, Baton Rouge, La.	Ezekiel John Ellis, attorney and congressman, was born Oct. 15, 1840, in St. Tammany Parish, La., to Ezekiel Parke Ellis and Tabitha Warner Ellis. He received his early education in Covington and Clinton, La., and later attended Centenary College at Jackson, La., graduating in 1858. He studied law at the University of Louisiana in New Orleans (now Tulane University) obtaining his law degree in 1861. At the onset of the Civil War, he enlisted in the Confederate army as a first lieutenant and was later promoted to captain in the 16th Louisiana Infantry Regiment, Army of Tennessee. His regiment participated in the Confederate Heartland Offensive. He was sent to Johnson Island, Lake Erie, Ohio, after his capture at the Battle of Missionary Ridge in February of 1863. He remained a prisoner at Johnson Island for the duration of the war and was paroled in June of 1865. After the war he returned to Amite, where he served as editor to the Amite Daily Wanderer until 1866, and then moved to Covington to open a law practice. Ellis was an active member of the Democratic Party, serving in Louisiana State Senate (1866-1870) and the United States House of Representative (1875-1885). He also held the position of chairman of the Committee on Mississippi Levees and was a key figure in the Wormley House Conference that helped resolve the disputed election of 1876 in Louisiana. After leaving Congress, he resumed the practice of law in Washington, D.C., where he died April 25, 1889.
